DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Brave Savannah Snow For Funeral of Slain Alderman
Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from service, detail on weather; picks up 7th graf, `Hours before ...'
DOC.TEXT: About 450 mourners braved snow and freezing temperatures Saturday to attend the funeral of Alderman Robert Robinson, the civil rights attorney killed by a mail bomb and eulogized as someone who loved politics and people. ``He would never let you down,'' Savannah NAACP President Curtis Cooper told mourners at St. Paul's CME Church. ``He was the type of man who could walk with kings, but never lost the common touch.'' Robinson, 42, died Monday night shortly after a bomb mailed to his Savannah law office exploded as he opened it. He was the second victim of mail bombs federal officals believe might have been sent by racists with grudge against the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Robinson's death came two days after a similar bomb killed 11th Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance and seriously injured his wife at their home in a Birmingham, Ala., suburb. Despite the cold and more than 2 inches of snow in the Savannah area, mourners packed the church for Saturday's service. The Rev. Henry Delaney, pastor of St. Paul's, said Saturday that Robinson's death might seem senseless, but is part of a higher political agenda for black Americans. Delaney said the death should be used to propel black politics in Georgia forward, without fear of racist retaliation. He pointed out that New York City elected its first black mayor shortly after a black teen-ager was shot to death in a predominantly white neighborhood. ``Don't you give up, Mrs. Robinson. Don't you give up, mother Robinson. Don't you give up, children,'' Delaney shouted, addressing Robinson's widow, mother and two children. ``Robbie was killed because he was a lawyer and because he sought to rectify wrongs,'' said Alderman Floyd Adams, his voice often cracking with emotion. ``If he were here, he would say `Don't look at this as a setback. Don't be discouraged.''' W.W. Law, a former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Robinson's life should serve as a role model for young people, to inspire them to help those shackled by social or economic injustice. ``There is so much instruction to be learned from this life,'' he said. ``He was the model of self-improvement and worked toward the improvement of his community.'' State Rep. Jim Pannell said Robinson's loss should strengthen people in their resolve to help each other. ``The bombs of hatred will not drive us back,'' he said. Hours before Robinson died, a parcel bomb was found at the 11th Circuit building in Atlanta. The next day, another one was discovered at the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. On Friday, a county circuit judge in Hagerstown, Md., was injured when a bomb exploded in his apartment 20 minutes after a package was delivered. FBI officials said preliminary reports indicated the incident was unrelated to the other bombings. FBI investigators have concentrated on possible racial motivations in the slayings. Robinson represented the NAACP in a desegregation case involving Savannah schools. Agents determined that Vance wrote an opinion in an unrelated Jacksonville school desegregation case in September that was a victory for the NAACP. A three-judge panel of the appeals court unanimously reversed a lower court's ruling that Jacksonville could stop busing students because the school system was integrated.
